contentrichtext.text: {{Cleanup|date=March 2010}} {{Refimprove|date=March 2010}} The '''music of [[Bahrain]]''' is part of the Persian Gulf folk traditions. Alongside [[Kuwait]], it is known for [[sawt (music)|sawt]] music, a [[blues]]y genre influenced by [[Africa]]n, [[India]]n and [[Persian traditional music|Persian music]]. Sultan Hamid, [[Ali Bahar]] and [[Khalid al Shaikh]] (a singer and [[oud]] player) are among the most popular musicians from Bahrain.<ref>Badley, Bill. "Sounds of the Arabian Peninsula". 2000. In Broughton, Simon and Ellingham, Mark with McConnachie, James and Duane, Orla (Ed.), ''World Music, Vol. 1: Africa, Europe and the Middle East'', pp 351-354. Rough Guides Ltd, Penguin Books. ISBN 1-85828-636-0</ref> Bahrain was the site of the first Persian Gulf-based [[recording studio]], established after [[World War II]].<ref name=AUC/> Modern music institutions in Bahrain include the [[Bahrain Music Institute]], the [[Bahrain Orchestra]] and the [[Classical Institute of Music]]. The Bahraini male-only [[pearl diving]] tradition is known for the songs called ''[[fidjeri]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Music of Bahrain's Pearl Divers|work=MSN Encarta|url=http://encarta.msn.com/media_461524711/Music_of_Bahrain%92s_Pearl_Divers.html|accessdate=September 28, 2005|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5kx7ZErcv|archivedate=2009-11-01|deadurl=yes}}</ref> [[Liwa (music)|Liwa]] and [[Fann at-Tanbura]] are types of music and dance performed mainly in communities of descendants of [[Bantu peoples]] from the [[African Great Lakes]] region. ==Khaleeji== {{Main|Khaliji (music)}} Khaleeji is a style of Persian Gulf-area folk music, played in Bahrain with [[polyrhythm]]s. The style is strongly influenced by the [[music of Africa]]. Khaleeji singer [[Ali Bahar]] is one of the few Bahraini pop stars to sing in a local dialect, along with his band [[Al Ekhwa]].<ref>{{cite web|work=Bahraini Blog|title=Ali Bahar|url=http://bahrainiblog.blogspot.com/2004/05/ali-bahar.html|accessdate=September 28, 2005}}</ref> ==Sawt== {{Main|sawt (music)}} In Bahrain, the early pioneers of ''sawt'' were Mohammed Faris and Dhabi bin Walid in the pre-World War II era. Both recorded their ''sawt'' music in [[HMV]]'s studio in [[Baghdad]] in 1932.<ref name=AUC/> Their recordings became widely popular in Bahrain and Kuwait.<ref name=AUC/> The Bahraini ''sawt'' style became the predominant style of ''sawt'' in the Gulf.<ref name=AUC>{{cite book|first=Michael Frishkopf|title=Music and Media in the Arab World|year=2010|publisher=American University in Cairo|isbn=9774162935|pages=114, 115, 116|url=http://books.google.com.bh/books?id=KANOAYzkhA8C&lpg=PA116&dq=bahrain%20world%20war&pg=PA114#v=onepage&q=bahrain%20world%20war&f=false}}</ref> ==Modern era== The band Bahraini [[Osiris (band)|Osiris]] has achieved some international renown since the 1980s with its style of [[progressive rock]], most recently including elements of Bahraini folk music.<ref>{{cite web|title=Osiris Band|work=Bahrain|url=http://www.webpost.net/os/osirisband/OSIRIS1.HTM|accessdate=September 28, 2005}}</ref> There is also a strong [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] and [[Hard rock]] community in the country, with many groups writing and performing original songs. The 3 main bands in the history of the community include [[thrash metal]] band [[Motör Militia]], Black Metal band [[Smouldering in Forgotten]] and Death Metal band [[Lunacyst]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.bahrainona.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=122&Itemid=134 Bahrain Music] ==Further reading== *{{cite book|title=Music in Bahrain|author=Rovsing Olsen, Poul|year=2002|publisher=David Brown Book Company|isbn=87-88415-19-8}} *{{cite book|title=Sawt of Bahrein|author=Muhammad Bin Faris Ensemble|year=2004|publisher=Institut Du Monde|id=[http://www.amazon.com/o/ASIN/B00025DQEU ASIN B00025DQEU]}} *{{cite book|title=A Musical Anthology of the Arabian Peninsula, Volume 3 – Sowt, Music from the City|author=Various artists|year=1995|publisher=Gallo|id=[http://www.amazon.com/o/ASIN/B000004A2E ASIN B000004A2E]}} *{{cite book|title=Fidjeri:Songs Of The Bahrain Pearl Divers|author=Various artists|year=2000|publisher=UNESCO|id=[http://www.amazon.com/o/ASIN/B00000AU93 ASIN B00000AU93]}} *{{cite book|title=A Musical Anthology of the Arabian Peninsula, Volume 2 – Music of the Pearl Divers|author=Various artists|year=1995|publisher=Gallo|id=[http://www.amazon.com/o/ASIN/B000004A2D ASIN B000004A2D]}} {{Middle Eastern music}} {{Music of Asia}} [[Category:Bahraini music| ]]
